results.title: Information processing (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bruce Hart, Carole Hart and Communication Research Media Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology Today”.
Using for its base a crowded noisy cocktail party as observed from a control booth, analyses how people process information. Pretty girls and bizarrely dressed men demonstrate attention, language processing, long and short term memory, mnemonics, retrieval strategies, and problem solving.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bruce Hart, Carole Hart and Communication Research Media Productions

results.title: Aspects of behaviour (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bruce Hart and Communication Research Media Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology Today”.
Relating psychology to the student’s life experience this film considers ethical issues such as obedience and authority along with prejudice and attitude change. It also examines questions like: what does a social psychologist do? How does physiology relate to behaviour? Do psychologists often agree? What is cultural psychology?

results.title: Psychology for Living
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Toward emotional security
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology for Living”.
Aims to assist adolescents in understanding and controlling their emotions. Tells of an eighteen-year-old girl, faced with a decision involving her feelings for her parents and a young man. She recalls episodes from her early life in which love, fear and hate were not always controlled and is then able to make a decision that shows her emotional growth.

results.title: Successful scholarship
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology for Living”
Assists students in developing sound study methods by depicting techniques worked out by a student of nursing who has adapted hospital routines to the forming of study habits based on three concepts: systematic planning, a suitable place for study and concentration, a definite method for assimilating the content of each assignment.

results.title: Heredity and family environment
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology for Living”.
Through a dramatised study of a high-school student, shows that individuals are joint products of heredity and environment. Discusses the roles of heredity and environment, how they mesh in actual living, voluntary and involuntary actions, and the physical effects of emotion.

results.title: Habit Patterns
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology for Living”.
It’s a little late for tears, isn’t it Barabara? Says the brutal narrator at the beginning of the film. This instructional piece, as the title suggests, is for developing good habits. At the start of the film, Barbara stands by the closed door of her bedroom, weeping pitifully. She has bad habits, and this film sends her to social hell as we flash-back to the beginning of her day. She is sloppy and unorganised, sleeps in, and is generally discourteous. All the examples of problems caused by her bad habits in this film are social blunders, which get worse as the film progresses. The narrator is unforgiving: “How easy it is not to be invited again.” and “how quickly you can be left out of the crowd”. This film is more about conformity than keeping good habits.

group_works.title: Reinforcement in learning and extinction
group_works.creator_credit: Herbert Kerkow and Herbert Kerkow Productions

results.title: Reinforcement in learning and extinction
results.creator_credit: Herbert Kerkow and Herbert Kerkow Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology”.
Shows how learning is reinforced through stimulus-responses and extinguished when not reinforced, but rapidly reacquired when once more reinforced. Pigeons are used to demonstrate this learning process through responding through such stimuli as a hole in the wall, food, buzzer, and light. Removal of rewards makes them “forget” and return of reward reintroduces the learning almost immediately.
results.description:
